Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

The second part of the second chapter on distinguishing faculties. Now we should contemplate: As all conditioned things have different characteristics, their arising is also different. Are there any dharmas that definitely arise together, or are there any that definitely arise together?
Namely, all dharmas are roughly divided into five categories:
First, form; second, mind; third, mental factors; fourth, formations not associated with mind; fifth, unconditioned dharmas.
Unconditioned dharmas have no arising, so they are not discussed here.
Now, first we will explain the definite arising together of form.
Verse:ğŸ”½In desire [realms], subtle aggregates without sound,
Without faculties have eight things,
With body faculties nine things, Ten things with other faculties.
Commentary:
The most subtle aggregation of form is called a subtle aggregate, to show that there is nothing more subtle than this.
In the desire realm, without sound and without faculties, eight things arise together, not lacking any one.
What are the eight things?
That is, the four great elements and the four derivative forms of color, smell, taste, and touch.
In a cluster of atoms without sound and with faculties, the simultaneous events are either nine or ten.
A cluster of atoms with the body faculty has nine events simultaneously arising, with the body as the ninth, the other eight being as above.
A cluster of atoms with other faculties has ten events simultaneously arising, with the other faculties as the tenth, the first nine being as above.
The eye, ear, nose, and tongue faculties are definitely not separate from the body, because they are each located in a different place.

If sound arises in the above clusters, they increase in number by one, ten, and eleven respectively. This is because there is sound that arises without being separate from the faculties, namely that which arises from appropriated great elements.
If the four great elements arise without being separate from each other, why is it that in various clusters, solidity, moisture, heat, and motion are only perceived as one and not the other?
In those clusters, that which has the greatest power is clearly perceived, while the others are not non-existent.
It is like perceiving the touch of a needle tip when it joins with a stick, or like perceiving the taste of salt when it joins with flour.
How do we know that the other three exist there?
Because there is the function of cohesion, ripening, growth, and support.ğŸ”½Some say that when the primary elements encounter conditions, fluidity, etc., arise.
Just as in a mass of water, heat exists but the function of cold predominates, just as feeling and sound may predominate.
Other masters say that in this mass the other seeds exist but not their actual essences.
A scripture says, As in a pile of wood there are various seeds.
Seeds means seeds.
How do we know that color exists in wind?
This can be believed but cannot be inferred.
Or else, because the combined odor can be grasped, and odor is not separate from color.

We have already said that in the realm of form there is no odor or taste, and therefore there are six, seven, or eight kinds of dharmas in the realm of form, excluding sound. Where there is sound, there are seven or eight kinds, and where there is sound and tactile objects, there are eight kinds.
This can be understood by analogy, and therefore we do not discuss it separately.
Here, when it is said that substance is the basis, does it refer to the substance itself or to the location?
If so, what is the problem?
There is a problem in both cases.
If it refers to the substance itself, then eight, nine, or ten would be too few, because any aggregation of atoms must have shape and color, since many atoms accumulate together.
Weight and lightness must be present, and smoothness and roughness must also be present.
Or in some places there is cold, hunger, and thirst. In this case, what is said is too few.

If it refers to the location, then eight, nine, or ten would be too many, because the four great elements are included in the category of touch. It should be said that there are only four. In this case, what is said is too much.
There is no problem in either case.
It should be understood that what is called substance here refers to part of the substance itself, namely the supported great elements;
and part refers to the location, namely the derivative form that depends on it.
If so, then the substance of the great elements should become many, because derivative form is individually based on one great element.
You should know that in this passage, the four great elements are discussed in terms of their general nature, because there is no distinction in the general nature of the four great elements.
What is the use of analyzing such a statement?
Words arise according to desire, but the meaning should be investigated.
Thus far, the arising of form and concentration has been discussed.
The arising of the other concentrations will now be discussed.
Verse:
Mind and mental factors necessarily arise together, and the characteristics and attainments of all activities.
Treatise:
Mind and mental factors necessarily arise together. If one is missing, the other will not arise.
All activities refer to all conditioned phenomena, namely form, mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with mind.

The previous phrase necessarily together extends to this point. That is, when form, mind, etc., and all activities arise, they necessarily arise together with the four characteristics of conditioned phenomena.
The phrase or attainment means that among all activities, only sentient beings' dharmas arise together with attainment;
other dharmas are not like this. Therefore, the text says or.
Previously, it was said that mental factors. What are they?
Verse:
Mental factors are generally of five types, distinguished by the great ground dharmas, etc.
The treatise says:
Mental factors are generally of five types.
What are the five?
First, the great ground dharmas;
second, the great wholesome ground dharmas;
third, the great afflictive ground dharmas;
fourth, the great unwholesome ground dharmas;
fifth, the minor afflictive ground dharmas.
Ground means the place of activity. If this is the place of activity of that, then this is said to be the ground of that dharma.

Because it is the great ground of dharmas, it is called the great ground. If a dharma is possessed by the great ground, it is called a great ground dharma, meaning a dharma that always exists in all minds.
What are those dharmas?
The verse says:
Feeling, conceptualization, volition, contact, desire, wisdom, mindfulness, and attention,
Resolve, and samÄdhi, are found in all minds.ğŸ”½The treatise says:
It is explained:
It is said that these ten dharmas are universally present in a single moment of mind.
Feeling is the three kinds of sensation:
painful, pleasant, and neither, because there are differences.
Conception is the grasping of the characteristics of an object.
Volition is that which causes the mind to be active.
Contact is that which is born from the union of faculty, object, and consciousness, and is able to make contact.
Desire is the longing for an activity.
Wisdom is the discernment of dharmas.
Memory is the clear recollection of an object.
Attention is that which causes the mind to be alert.
Resolve is that which affirms an object.
Concentration is the one-pointedness of the mind.
The differences in characteristics of the various mental activities are subtle, and each continuum is difficult to distinguish, much less the simultaneous presence of all in one moment.
Even the differences in taste of colored medicines taken by the colored faculties are difficult to know, much less formless dharmas that are grasped only by cognition.
Thus far, the ten universal mental activities have been explained.

The stage of great wholesome dharmas is called the stage of great wholesomeness. The dharmas that exist in this stage are called the dharmas of the stage of great wholesomeness, which means that these dharmas always exist in wholesome minds.
What are these dharmas?
The verse says:
Faith, heedfulness, tranquility, equanimity, shame, embarrassment,
Two roots, and harmlessness - diligence is only universal in wholesome minds.
The treatise says:
These dharmas are only universal in wholesome minds.
Among them, faith causes the mind to become clear and pure.
Some say:
Because one clearly accepts and affirms the truths, reality, and karmic fruits, it is called faith.
Heedfulness means cultivating wholesome dharmas and avoiding unwholesome dharmas.
What else is called cultivation?
It means that this [heedfulness] has the nature of focusing exclusively on the wholesome.
In the sÅ«tras of other schools, there is such an explanation:
Being able to guard the mind is called heedfulness.
Tranquility means the adaptability of the mind.
How can it be that the sÅ«tras also speak of physical tranquility?
Although there is no explicit statement, you should understand that it is the same as the case of bodily feeling. How can you establish this as a factor of enlightenment?
You should understand that in this case, bodily lightness means the fitness of the body.
How can it be said to be a factor of enlightenment?
There is no error, because it is in conformity with the factors of enlightenment.
This is because bodily lightness can induce mental lightness, which is a factor of enlightenment.
Is there any other case where this is said?
Yes, as a scripture says:
Joy and the factors that favor joy are called the factor of enlightenment that is joy.
Hatred and the causes of hatred are called the hindrance of hatred.
Right views, right thought, and right effort are called the aggregate of wisdom.

Although thought and effort are not by nature wisdom, they are called wisdom because they are in conformity with wisdom. Therefore there is no error in calling bodily lightness a factor of enlightenment because it is in conformity with it.
The evenness and nondiscursive nature of mind is called equanimity.
How can you say that in a single moment of mind there is a discursive nature and a nondiscursive nature?
It is associated with both attention and equanimity.
Wasnâ€™t it said previously that the characteristics of mind and its activities are subtle and difficult to know?
Although they are difficult to know, they can be known through careful investigation.
This is the most difficult to know, because they are contradictory and yet not contradictory.
One is aroused and the other is not. Since the two are so different, how can they be noncontradictory?
If this is so, then they should not have the same object, or else all dharmas would be mutually noncontradictory.
Other dharmas of this kind should be sought in this chapter, and we should understand them in the same way as they are treated here.
Shame and dishonor will be explained later.

The two roots are noncraving and nonhatred. Nondelusion is by nature wisdom, and therefore it was said previously that it is a part of the generally permeating mental activities. It is not repeated here as a part of the wholesome mental activities.
Nonharming is the absence of injury.
Vigor is by nature the arousal of mind.
Thus the great wholesome factors have been explained.

The great afflictions are called the great afflictions, and the factors that are always present in the great afflictions are called the great afflictions. That is, the factors that are always present in defiled minds.
What are those factors?
Verse:ğŸ”½Delusion, negligence, indolence, disbelief,
stupefaction, and agitation are always only defiled.
Treatise:
Here, delusion refers to stupidity, which is ignorance, non-wisdom, and non-manifestation.
Negligence means not cultivating wholesome dharmas, and is the counteragent to the cultivation of wholesome dharmas.
Indolence means laziness, the mind not being vigorous. It is the counteragent to effort mentioned above.
Disbelief means the mind is not clear and pure, and is the counteragent to faith mentioned above.
Stupefaction means stupefaction.
In the Abhidharma, it is said:
What is stupefaction?
It is the heaviness of the body, the heaviness of the mind, the unfitness of the body, the unfitness of the mind, the dullness of the body, and the dullness of the mind. This is called torpor.
This is a mental factor.
How is it called bodily?
Like the term bodily feeling, it is not a mistake.
Agitation means agitation, which makes the mind not tranquil.
There are only these six kinds, called the factors of the great grounds of defilement.
Isn't it said in the fundamental Abhidharma that there are ten factors of the great grounds of defilement, and that treatise does not mention torpor?
What are the ten?
They are lack of faith, laziness, forgetfulness, distraction, ignorance, incorrect knowledge, improper attention, wrong resolve, agitation, and negligence.
You now only know the words, but are not familiar with the meaning.
What is the meaning?

That is, forgetfulness, distraction, incorrect knowing, incorrect mental orientation, and wrong resolve. Since they have already been explained as being among the dharmas on the great stages, they should not be established again as dharmas on the great stages of defilement.
Just as the wholesome root of nondelusion has wisdom as its substance and therefore is not a dharma on the great stages of wholesomeness, so it is with these.

Defiled memory is called forgetfulness, defiled samÄdhi is called distraction, defiled discernment is called incorrect knowing, and defiled mental orientation and resolve are called incorrect mental orientation and wrong resolve. Therefore it is said that these five dharmas are not established as being on the great stages of defilement.
Are those dharmas on the great stages also on the great stages of defilement?
You should make four sentences.
The first sentence is the five dharmas of feeling, conceptualization, volition, contact, and desire.
The second sentence is the five dharmas of faithlessness, indolence, ignorance, agitation, and heedlessness.
The third sentence is the five dharmas of memory, etc., as explained above.
The fourth sentence is the exclusion of the above characteristics.
There is an opinion that wrong concentration is not the same as distraction. They make four alternatives which are different from the above.
Also, torpor is associated with all passions, but it is not said to be a great ground of defilement.
What is the error in this?
There is an opinion that
it should be mentioned, but it is not mentioned because it is in accord with concentration.
This means that those who practice torpor quickly generate concentration, not those who practice agitation.ğŸ”½Who practices torpor but not agitation?
Who practices agitation but not torpor?
These two are never not associated.
Even so, one should know that the practice is said to follow the predominance of the two.

Even though one knows that the practice is said to follow the predominance of the two, still the ground of dharmas is established on the basis of that which exists. Therefore these ground dharmas are established as only six, because they are only found in defiled minds and are not the others.
This concludes the explanation of the dharmas of the great ground of defilement.

The name of the stage of great unwholesome dharmas is the stage of great unwholesomeness. The dharmas that exist in this stage are called the dharmas of the stage of great unwholesomeness, meaning the dharmas that always exist in unwholesome minds.
What are those dharmas?
Verse:
Only the universal unwholesome mental factors, namely shamelessness and lack of conscience.
Discussion:
Only two mental factors are concomitant with all unwholesome minds, namely shamelessness and lack of conscience. Therefore, only these two are called the dharmas of this stage.
The characteristics of these two dharmas will be discussed later.
Thus far, the dharmas of the stage of great unwholesomeness have been explained.

The name of the stage of minor afflictions is the stage of minor afflictions. The dharmas that exist in this stage are called the dharmas of the stage of minor afflictions, meaning the dharmas that are partially concomitant with defiled minds.
What are those dharmas?
Verse:
Anger, concealment, stinginess, envy, vexation, harmfulness, resentment, deceit, flattery, and arrogance -
Dharmas of this kind are called the dharmas of the stage of minor afflictions.
Discussion:

These kinds of dharmas are eliminated only by cultivation, arise in the stage of mental consciousness, are associated with ignorance, and each manifests separately. Therefore they are called minor defilements.
These dharmas will be extensively distinguished later in the chapter on secondary afflictions.
Thus far the five categories of mental activities have been discussed.
There are also other indeterminate mental activities such as remorse, sloth, applied thought, sustained thought, and so on, which should be discussed here.
In what mental states and in how many of them are the mental activities definitely generated together?
Verse:
Because desire has applied thought and sustained thought,ğŸ”½in a good mental state there are twenty-two mental activities.
Sometimes remorse increases to twenty-three.
In non-good and non-universal, and in those associated with views, there are only twenty.
In the four passions and anger, etc., there are twenty-one with remorse.
In the hindered-unwholesome there are eighteen, and in the unhindered-unwholesome twelve are allowed.
Sleepiness is universal and does not conflict with anything. If present, it increases by one in each case.
Treatise:ğŸ”½Herein, it should be discussed how many mental activities are definitely generated together in what mental states.
In the realm of desire, there are five classes of mental activities: good, which is one class;
bad, which is two classes, that associated with non-shared ignorance and that associated with other passions;
nondetermined, which is two classes, that with a nature of covering and that with a nature of non-covering.

However, because the mind in the realm of desire definitely has initial and sustained thought, the class of good mind definitely has twenty-two mental activities born together with it, that is, ten universal activities, ten good activities, and two undetermined activities, namely, initial thought and sustained thought.
Not all good minds have remorse, and sometimes the number increases to twenty-three.
What is remorse?
The substance of remorse for evil is called remorse.

You should know that in this context, the dharma of remorse for evil is called remorse, that is, the nature of the mind that regrets evil, just as the gate of liberation of emptiness is called emptiness, and non-greed regarding impurity is called impurity.
Also, in the world, on the basis of the place where something is located, one speaks of the thing itself, as when it is said, â€œAll the villages, towns, and countries have come to the assembly.â€
Regret is the basis of remorse, and therefore it is said that remorse is based on regret.
Also, a name for a result is figuratively used to refer to a cause, as when it is said, â€œThese six sense bases should be known as past action.â€
If one regrets something that has not been done, how can it be called regret?
A name for an action is also figuratively used to refer to something that has not been done, as when one regrets and says, â€œI did not do such and such an action in the past. This is my regret.â€
What kind of regret is called good?
It is the nature of the mind to regret not doing good and doing evil.
That which is contrary to this is called bad.

These two are each based on two places and arise. If in a class of unwholesome minds not common to all, there are definitely twenty mental activities born together, namely, the ten universal mental activities, the six fundamental passions, the two fundamental secondary passions, and the two variables, applied thought and sustained thought.
What are called classes of unwholesome minds not common to all?
It is said that in these classes of minds there is only ignorance and no other passions such as craving.
In classes of unwholesome minds associated with views, there are also twenty mental activities born together, the names of which are the same as those in the class not common to all.
There are not twenty-one because the view is not dominant. It is said that the function of discernment among the ten universal mental activities is called view.
As for minds associated with unwholesome views, it is said that in these minds there is either wrong views, or attachment to views, or attachment to dharmas.

In the class of minds with the four unwholesome passions of craving, hatred, pride, and doubt, twenty-one mental activities are generated simultaneously, twenty as above in the class not shared with the disciples, plus the addition of one of the three passions of craving, etc.

In the class of secondary passions such as anger, etc., that are associated with the above, twenty-one mental activities are generated simultaneously, twenty as above in the class not shared with the disciples, plus the addition of one of the secondary passions such as anger, etc.
In the class of minds associated with unwholesome remorse, twenty-one mental activities are generated simultaneously, i.e., the above twenty plus remorse as the twenty-first.

In brief, it should be said that in the class of unwholesome mental activities not shared with the disciples and in the class associated with views, there are only twenty mental activities; in the other classes associated with the four passions and secondary passions, there are twenty-one.

In the class of minds with passions that are morally neutral and that cover over the true nature of objects, only eighteen mental activities are generated simultaneously, i.e., the ten universal activities, the six secondary passions, plus two of the undetermined activities, i.e., applied thought and sustained thought.

In the desire realm, the indeterminate mind with hindrances refers to that associated with the view of a real self and the view grasping an extreme. The view does not increase here, and it should be understood as explained above.

In the other indeterminate and unrestrained mind categories, it is admitted that only twelve mental activities are present, namely, the ten universal mental activities and the two undetermined mental activities of initial and sustained thought.
Masters of other regions want to have remorse also in the indeterminate class, and then there are twelve mental activities present in this associated category.
You should understand that drowsiness is not incompatible with any of the above-mentioned mind categories, because it is of a good, bad, or indeterminate nature.
When it is present in a category, it is said to increase by one, from twenty-two to twenty-three, and from twenty-three to twenty-four.
The same principle should be used to understand the bad and indeterminate states.
We have explained the definite number of mental activities associated with the various mind categories in the desire realm. We shall now discuss the upper realms.
A verse says:
In the first trance state, remove the bad mind and remorse and drowsiness.
In the middle concentration, investigation is also removed, and in the upper [concentrations], it and the rest are removed.
The treatise says:
In the first meditative absorption, among the mental factors mentioned above, only the unwholesome, contrition, and sleep are excluded, the rest are all present.
The only unwholesome ones are the afflictions of anger, excluding deceit, flattery, and pride, as well as the remaining resentments and so on, and lack of conscience and shame.
The rest are all present, as explained in the desire realm.
In the intermediate meditative absorption, the above exclusions are removed, and investigation is further removed, the rest are all present.
In the second meditative absorption and above, up to the formless realm, the above exclusions are removed, and the rest such as initial thought are also removed.
The rest are all present as before.
The sÅ«tras say:
Deceit and flattery extend only to the Brahma Heaven, because the characteristics depend on each other, and there is none above that.
Because the Great Brahma King, while in his own Brahma assembly, was suddenly asked by the bhiká¹£u AÅ›vajit:
In what state do these four elements completely cease without remainder?
The Brahma King does not know the state of complete cessation, so he gives a false and confused answer:
I am the Great Brahma in this Brahma assembly, the creator, transformer, producer, and nourisher, the father of all.
Having said this, he leads them outside the assembly and with flattery and apologies tells them to return and ask the Buddha.
Having explained the number of mental factors in each mind state in the various realms and stages, we will now explain some distinctions among the mental factors discussed above.
What are the distinctions between shamelessness, disregard, love, and respect?
Verse:
Shamelessness and disregard are not respecting and fearing offenses,
Love and respect are faith and shame, only existing in the desire and form realms.
Treatise:

Here, the distinction between shamelessness and disregard is this: not respecting, not revering, not being afraid of, and not following and submitting to merits and those who possess merits is called shamelessness, which is the opposite of respect.
The dharmas that are despised by good people are called faults. Not seeing fear in these faults is called shamelessness.
The term â€œsinâ€ refers to dharmas that are despised by good people. The term â€œfearâ€ refers to the fact that undesirable results can produce fear.
What is the meaning of the phrase â€œnot seeing fearâ€?
Does it mean to see and not be afraid, or does it mean not to see fear?
What is wrong with either interpretation?
Both interpretations are wrong.
If it means to see and not be afraid, then it should reveal wisdom. If it means not to see fear, then it should reveal ignorance.
This phrase does not reveal either seeing or not seeing. What does it reveal?
It reveals a dharma that is an accompanying affliction and is the cause of both of the above two. It is called shamelessness.
Other masters say:
Self-contempt for having committed a sin is called shamelessness, and contempt for others for having committed a sin is called lack of conscience.
If that is so, since these two have different objects, how can they occur simultaneously?
We do not say that these two occur simultaneously and have different objects.
However, there is shamelessness that observes oneself when superior and is called lack of conscience.
There is also shamelessness that observes others when increased and is called lack of embarrassment.

The distinction between conscience and shame should be understood as the opposite of this, namely, the opposite of the first explanation is having respect, having reverence, having something to avoid, and having something to follow, which is called conscience. Seeing fear in offenses is called shame.
The opposite of the second explanation is having shame in oneself when committing offenses, which is called conscience, and having shame in others, which is called shame.
The distinction between lack of conscience and shame has already been explained.
The difference between affection and respect is that affection means fondness, which is precisely faith.
However, there are two kinds of affection:
one is defiled, and the other is undefiled.
The defiled is craving, such as affection for wife and children, etc.
The undefiled is faith, such as affection for teachers and elders, etc.ğŸ”½There is faith that is not affection, namely, faith in regard to suffering and its cause.
There is affection that is not faith, namely, defiled affection.
There is that which is both faith and love, namely, faith in cessation and the path.
There is that which is neither faith nor love, namely, excluding the above three characteristics.
Some say:
Faith is the acquiescence in and approval of virtue. Love arises only after this as a prior condition. Therefore love is not faith.
Respect is reverence. Its substance is precisely shame. As explained above, shame is that which has respect, etc.
There is shame that is not respect, namely, shame with regard to suffering and its causes.
There is that which is both shame and respect, namely, shame with regard to cessation and the path.
Some say:
Respect is that which is revered. Shame and abashment arise only after this as a prior condition. Therefore respect is not shame.
With regard to the person as the objective realm, love and respect may be either present or absent. Four sentences are appropriate.
There is that which is love but not respect, namely, with regard to wife, children, fellow students, and disciples, etc.
There is that which is respect but not love, namely, with regard to the teacher of others, virtuous and noble persons, etc.
There is that which is both love and respect, namely, with regard to one's own teacher, parents, uncles, and cousins, etc.
There is that which is neither love nor respect, namely, excluding the above three characteristics.
Thus, love and respect exist in the desire and form realms, but not in the formless realm.
How can it be that shame and conscience, which are great wholesome factors, do not exist in the formless realm?

There are two kinds of love and respect: that which takes the Dharma as its object and that which takes pudgalas as its object. Love and respect that take the Dharma as their object exist in all three realms.
Here, the meaning refers to that which takes pudgalas as its object, therefore it exists in the desire and form realms, but not in the formless realm.
Thus, the distinctions in love and respect have been explained.
What are the distinctions between investigation, analysis, pride, and arrogance?
Verse:
Investigation and analysis are the coarseness and subtlety of the mind. Pride is the exaltation of the mind towards others.
Arrogance is the intoxication with one's own qualities. The mind is haughty and does not look up to others.
Treatise:

The difference between investigation and analysis is that they are the coarseness and subtlety of the mind. The coarse nature of the mind is called investigation, and the subtle nature of the mind is called analysis.
How can these two be associated with a single mind?
There is an explanation for this:
It is like floating raw ghee on cold water, which is touched by the scorching sunlight. The ghee is neither melted nor solidified due to the water and sun.
In the same way, the one mind has both investigation and analysis. The mind is not universally subtle or coarse due to investigation and analysis, so they both function together in the one mind.

If that is so, then investigation and analysis are the causes of coarseness and subtlety, not the essence of coarseness and subtlety, just as water and sunlight are the causes of melting and solidifying, but the essence of water and sunlight is neither melting nor solidifying.

Moreover, the natures of coarseness and subtlety are established in mutual dependence. The distinctions of realms, stages, and categories are formed by the upper and lower [natures]. Up to the peak of existence, there should be investigation and analysis.
Moreover, the natures of coarseness and subtlety have no separate substance. It is not possible to distinguish investigation and analysis based on them.
There is another interpretation:
The two dharmas of investigation and analysis are the activities of language. Therefore a sutra says:
Only when there is investigation and analysis are there verbal activities. Without investigation and analysis, these verbal activities do not exist.

The gross one is called applied thought, and the subtle one is called sustained thought. What is wrong with the principle that in one mind there are separate dharmas that are gross and separate dharmas that are subtle?
If there are separate species, there is no contradiction in principle.
However, there are no separate species, and therefore there is a contradiction with principle, because in one species there cannot be both the high and the low occurring simultaneously.
If you say that the species also have differences in substance, then you must explain what the specific characteristics of the differences in substance are.

The specific characteristics of the differences in substance of these two are difficult to explain. They are only manifested by the high and low, and the high and low cannot manifest the specific characteristics, because the high and low exist in each species.
Therefore you should understand that applied thought and sustained thought are definitely not to be grasped as associated with one mind.
If this is so, then how do we explain the statement in the scriptures?
The first trance state is complete with five members.
The statement that it is complete with five members is made with reference to one stage, not to one moment, and therefore there is no error.
The differences between applied thought and sustained thought have been discussed in this way.

The difference between pride and arrogance is that pride is the nature of the mind exalting itself in relation to others. It is called pride because it is the mind exalting itself and despising others based on the distinction of the differences in virtue and so on between oneself and others.
Arrogance is the nature of the mind being unrestrained due to being intoxicated with one's own qualities.
Some say:
Just as the distinction of joy and elation born from alcohol is called intoxication, so the distinction of joy and elation born from craving is called arrogance.
This is the difference between pride and arrogance.
Thus, the various categories and differences in the arising of the mind and mental factors have been explained.
However, the mind and mental factors are established with various names and concepts in the sÅ«tras according to their meanings. Now, their differences in names and meanings will be discussed.
The verse states:
The substance of mind, thought, and consciousness is one, and the mind and mental factors have a basis,
An object, and aspects. The meaning of association is fivefold.
The treatise states:
It is called mind because it accumulates and produces, it is called thought because it thinks and reflects, and it is called consciousness because it distinguishes and cognizes.
There is another interpretation:

It is called mind because it is the various distinctions of pure and impure realms. It is called thought because it serves as the support for others. It is called consciousness because it serves as the support for itself.
Therefore, although the meanings expressed by the three names mind, thought, and consciousness are different, their substance is the same.
